<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fhealthcare%20systems%20and%20services%2Four%20insights%2Ffinding%20solidarity%20in%20an%20effort%20to%20vaccinate%20the%20world%2Ffinding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world-vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world-vf" data-layer-report-name="finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world-vf>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (6 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>As long as COVID-19 is out there, </strong>its a threat. Unless vaccine supplies are shared more equitably, its estimated that the worlds poorest countries will not be able to reach a vaccination rate of 60 percent until 2023 or later.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3e61db6b-4b7a-41ee-8568-aa4696b05019"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3e61db6b-4b7a-41ee-8568-aa4696b05019" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Atthar Mirza and Emily Rauhala, Heres just how unequal the global coronavirus vaccine rollout has been, <em>Washington Post</em>, May 6, 2021, washingtonpost.com.
    </span></span></span></a></span> In many ways, the impacts of that timeline could be more devastating than the immediate crisis. With disproportionate global vaccine distribution and growing concerns over the emergence of more contagious COVID-19 variants, the required protection becomes much harder to reachvery possibly extending the length of the pandemic.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About this series: <em>COVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond</em></div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This interview is part of the series <em>COVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond</em>. By drawing on the experience of private- and public-sector experts across a wide range of perspectivesfrom vaccine innovation to manufacturing, distribution, and accessibilitywe aim to help leaders navigate recovery efforts for the COVID-19 pandemic and share some of the lessons theyve learned to combat the pandemic and support the future of vaccines. Articles in the series include interviews with the heads of top global health organizations, government agencies, and vaccine manufacturers. For example:</p>
<ul>
    <li><a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery">Africa CDC: Africas plan for a continent-wide pandemic recovery</a></li>
    <li><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/accelerating-pandemic-response-efforts-an-interview-with-cepis-richard-hatchett">Accelerating pandemic response efforts: An interview with CEPIs Richard Hatchett</a> </li>
    <li><a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world">Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance: Finding solidarity in an effort to vaccinate the world</a></li>
    <li><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/modernas-path-to-vaccine-innovation-a-talk-with-ceo-stephane-bancel">Modernas path to vaccine innovation: A talk with CEO Stphane Bancel</a></li>
    <li><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pfizers-mix-of-science-and-grit-alters-the-course-of-its-covid-19-response">Pfizers mix of science and grit alters the course of its COVID-19 response</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Along with public-health authorities, we recognize that vaccination is critical to combating infectious diseases, and we are committed to the urgent effort of bringing an end to the COVID-19 pandemic and transforming the future of immunization.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Dr. Seth Berkley is the CEO of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, which was built to help low-income countries obtain vaccines. He knows better than most, from decades of work on vaccines, that closing immunity gaps globally is a Herculean task. But he also sees progress and a renewed cooperation and collaboration among his partners to deal with vaccine distribution more equitably. Gavi co-leads (with CEPI and WHO) COVAX, which supports the research, development, and manufacturing of a wide range of COVID-19-vaccine candidates and is the biggest global effort in history to get vaccines to developing nations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a08df41d-e711-409e-a126-289d2f2b39e3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a08df41d-e711-409e-a126-289d2f2b39e3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Seth Berkley, COVAX explained, Gavi, September 3, 2020, gavi.org.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<!-- -->
<p>Gavi is in a unique position to address inequities in COVID-19-vaccine access. As the secretariat
of an alliance comprising UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank, along with other leading global health agencies, vaccine manufacturers, and the private sector, it has spent two decades funding vaccines for lower-income countries. But one of the most important strategies for making real headway in a crisis of this magnitude is to evolve the working relationships among the alliances flagship organizations to heighten the core immunization measures.</p>
<p>Dr. Berkley talks with McKinseys Michael Conway and Lieven Van der Veken about how he is reactivating private and public resources toward one of the biggest societal challenges in history. What follows is an edited excerpt of their conversation.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>Gavis mission is to secure vaccines for developing countries. How are you doing that with the COVID-19 vaccines?</p>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Seth Berkley:</strong> Historically, vaccines dont get to the poorest nations. Over the past 20 years, Gavis public- and private-sector collaborations have provided close to 50 percent of the worlds children with vaccines and have been able to launch more than 495 new vaccine introductions and campaigns all across the world. </p>
<p>In 2020, given the importance of the COVID-19 outbreak, we helped launch a partnership called COVAX to accelerate the development and manufacturing of COVID-19 vaccines and guarantee fair and equitable access to them for every country in the world. So far, 193 countries and territories have come together to be part of this initiative. Through the COVAX Facility, the alliance went on to secure two billion doses of COVID-19 vaccines for the second half of 2021, with the goal of having every healthcare worker in the world immunized.</p>
<p>The hardest part at the beginning was not being able to move the deals as quickly as wed like and
not being able to deliver as quickly as wed like. But comparing the work of this crisis to the pandemic in 2009, we were two-and-a-half times faster and went to four times the number of countries with more than seven times the number of doses.</p>
<p>We still have a ways to go. More than 3.47 billion vaccine doses have been administered globally,
but while 49.6 percent of inhabitants of high-income countries had received at least one dose of the vaccine as of July 14, only 1 percent of those in low-income countries had.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="58f49d67-5302-4463-be12-dca126746a72"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="58f49d67-5302-4463-be12-dca126746a72" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Cameron Appel et al.,Coronavirus Pandemic (COVID-19), Our World in Data, 2021, ourworldindata.org.</span></span></span></a></span> We set up COVAX to try to get equity firmly on the agenda. We knew that had not happened in previous epidemics. We also had hoped to stop bilateral deal making as much as possible because we know that its not an efficient way to deal with the distribution of products equitably. Weve done very wellnot necessarily getting us to equity but at least having that as part of the conversation.</p>
<p>Concerning bilateral deals, there was excitement for a multilateral mechanism. People came together to work on it, but when the new variants appeared, some high- and low-income countries made additional purchases. This has led to the type of supply constraints that we knew were going to be there. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Coronavirus Vaccines Progress: Whats Next?" src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/coronavirus%20vaccines%20progress/vaccines-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Coronavirus vaccines progress: Whats next?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-vaccines-progress" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Explore the collection</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>McKinsey:</strong> Can you expand on the challenges of ongoing supply constraints and what can be done to quicken equitable vaccine distribution for COVID-19 and other vaccine-preventable diseases? </p>
<p><strong>Seth Berkley: </strong>At first, the challenge we had was getting the financing and the vaccine approvals. We initially moved forward with two different deals: one with AstraZeneca, and the other with the Serum Institute of India.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7870829e-a136-493b-b982-043870c5294f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7870829e-a136-493b-b982-043870c5294f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Gavi has since agreed upon a new vaccine collaboration to support a final list of 92 countries through the Gavi COVAX AMC. James Fulker, New collaboration makes further 100 million doses of COVID-19 vaccine available to low- and middle-income countries, Gavi, September 29, 2020, gavi.org.</span></span></span></a></span> The latter covered distribution to the poorest 60 countries, and the former covered the rest of the world. In early 2021, we began to deliver on both of these plans. It was a little slow at the start because of the magnitude of the effort, but then it started to take off. </p>
<p>But we knew this wasnt a fait accompli. There are new challenges that emerge every day during a pandemic of this scale, like the rise of new variants that test the efficacy of current vaccines, vaccine hesitancy in some countries over risk concerns, and the terrible surge of infections in India. These challenges impose additional stress on an already strained supply chain for delivering vaccines to developing countries.
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>There are new challenges that emerge every day during a pandemic of this scale .... These challenges impose additional stress on an already 
strained supply chain for delivering vaccines to developing countries.</p></blockquote></div>
</p>
<p>The entire world was producing about five billion doses of all types of vaccines per year prior to the pandemic. Estimates reveal a further ten billion to 14 billion doses will be needed to include COVID-19 vaccines.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="aeaf7b82-5329-411a-be20-7d113fe75f8c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="aeaf7b82-5329-411a-be20-7d113fe75f8c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Towards vaccinating the world: Landscape of current COVID-19 supply chain and manufacturing capacity, potential challenges, initial responses, and possible solution space, </em>Global COVID-19 Vaccine Supply Chain & Manufacturing Summit, March 9, 2021, ifpma.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Thats a tripling of volume. Serious challenges with the supply chain will need to be dealt with. </p>
<p>So far, were still seeing routine vaccines being supplied at about the same pace as they were before the COVID-19 pandemic. But considering the current global shortages, the production is likely to slow down. In some places, a lack of routine vaccine distribution could lead to additional complexities. Theres a study that suggests that due to the efforts in preventing just one COVID-19-related death, there could be 84 deaths from other vaccine-preventable diseases.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5960d006-76f7-4b65-b56b-ffa8a797cd29"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5960d006-76f7-4b65-b56b-ffa8a797cd29" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kaja Abbas et al., Routine childhood immunisation during the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa: A benefitrisk analysis of health benefits versus excess risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection, <em>Lancet Global Health</em>, October 1, 2020, Volume 8, Number 10, pp. E126472, thelancet.com.</span></span></span></a></span> We want to avoid that type of trade-off. An outbreak of a vaccine-preventable disease would also compound the problem by doubly overwhelming the healthcare system and healthcare workers.</p>
<p>Over the longer term, we need to solve for building a more equitable manufacturing system for vaccines and make sure they are produced in different regions across different countries. We clearly
need more localized capacity, but it also has to be economically viable for those regions.</p>

<!-- --><p><strong>McKinsey:</strong> Gavi has always relied on strong partnerships. What has been the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on your collaborations? Has there been an upside? </p>
<p><strong>Seth Berkley: </strong>One of the advantages that Gavi has is that its an alliance. We have working relationships with WHO, the World Bank, and UNICEF, as well as civil society and vaccine manufacturers. Were working together every day with all of these different groups. We can bring those existing relationships together in a network-type operation versus a more siloed approach. In April 2020, this way of working resulted in the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator, which supports the development of all the tools needed to fight the diseasenot just the vaccines but the diagnostics, treatments, and therapeutics needed globally as well.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b2798da1-f855-4785-8361-eeb87cf00030"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b2798da1-f855-4785-8361-eeb87cf00030" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Access to COVID-19 Tools (ACT) Accelerator, WHO, accessed June 25, 2021, who.int. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>This network approach is how both the surge capacity and the ability to work in different ways can be done best. For example, initially, in the year 2001, we only worked with five private-sector companies, and four of the five were in wealthy countries. Today, we have 17 suppliers, and the majority of those are in developing countries. We not only had to work with some of the same manufacturers of the past but also had to introduce new competitors in the mix, and those manufacturers were under enormous pressure to deal with high-income governments. </p>
<p>And so the challenge has been to help lead these companies to balance their engagements in both developed and developing countries. That was very hard at the beginning. But through more cooperation and collaboration, this way of working provides faster and stronger decision-making powers across a whole range of institutions to respond quickly and focus on specific challenges as they arise and try to solve for those.</p>
<p>This network wave is the wave of the future. If you look at the big problems in the world, they are not going to be solved by just one group, whether its the private sector or governments. Theyre going to be solved by interesting collaborations between the private and public sectors and different groups and institutions working together. Thats how well get the balance of being both agile and representative: taking into account the politics but not being consumed by it and unable to move forward.</p>

<p><strong>McKinsey:</strong> The COVID-19 pandemic has been a very difficult and dynamic period. What lessons have been learned from it? Which do you think will last?</p>
<p><strong>Seth Berkley:</strong> The world has to be prepared. It is evolutionarily certain that we will have more outbreaks. What was quickly evident to me as we began this systematic approach was the number of things that were not in place.</p>
<p>The most trivial example was how we label the vaccines. Are they labeled for each individual country or region in different languages? Do we have a pandemic label? There were also more complicated examples. Do we have the system set up to deal with the issues of indemnification and liability and no-fault compensation? Do we have regulatory harmonizationare countries willing to accept, for example, WHO prequalification or emergency use authorization as a way forward?</p>
<p>Now that weve systematically put all of these measures in place, I think the challenge for us is, how do we keep them in place going forward? How do we take the existing organizations that
are working in these spaces and build the surge capacity and financial ability but also keep the lessons learned? That way, the next time there is a pandemic, we can just jump right in and use the tools that have been put in place.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey:</strong> In the area of innovation, what do you see as most promising in the fight against COVID-19 and other diseases?</p>
<p><strong>Seth Berkley:</strong> First of all, on the vaccine side, its been unbelievable. As somebody whos worked in vaccines for decades now, I was asked early on how long it takes to produce a new vaccine, and the fastest vaccine before this was produced in four years. The Ebola vaccine took five years. And
here we are, 327 days from the time the genomic sequence was done until we had a vaccine. That is extraordinary innovation. And not just one vaccine: there are 15 COVID-19 vaccines that have been approved for widespread use. </p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The Ebola vaccine took five years. And here we are, 327 days from the time the genomic sequence was done until we had a vaccine. That is extraordinary innovation.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Our hope is that some of these innovations can be pivoted to other diseases, whether they be regional diseaseslike Marburg or Congo hemorrhagic feveror whether the innovations are for diseases where we need a universal vaccinelike influenzaor better worklike HIV or tuberculosis. Id also like to see new tools to deliver vaccines. Can we use patch technologies? Can we use nasal or oral administrations that can make it easier to work in difficult settings, and ideally not at 80C? How do we achieve temperature stability?</p>
<p>Beyond vaccine innovation, we need to take advantage of the digital world and the ability to track and trace. We could use barcodes to follow vaccine distribution, with identifiers that allow us
to get real-time data that can help us manage stocks and the process better. This pandemic
has been an opportunity to test new systems and develop them for future use on routine
vaccines and other health commodities.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>We also have to think about how we innovate on the financing side, which has been an important part of what weve done. Its brought us into areas like innovating in insurance, which is not our normal strength but was really important. For example, we were able to create a no-fault compensation scheme for the 92 poorest countries. That had never been done before.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey:</strong> What are three things you want to see happen differently concerning the COVID-19 vaccines?</p>
<p><strong>Seth Berkley: </strong>The first thing I would like to see is COVID-19-vaccine doses freed up for the poorest countries. We are just not there yet concerning this critical issue of equity. Many countries are now donating back surplus doses, and I expect more will follow. </p>
<p>Second, I want to see the volumes increase everywhere so that we can take into account domestic needs at the same time that we look at global supply. </p>
<p>And lastand I think this is beginning to happenpeople need to understand that we are only safe if everyones safe. Its a natural response for people to say, Im worried about my family, my community, my country. But when you see a pandemic moving globally as fast as this one is, mutations occur. If there are large parts of the world that are unprotected, theres potential risk not just for those countries but for the whole world. So how do we move to a world that, in those circumstances, doesnt think nationally but thinks globally? Thats a critical part of the future vision of where we need to go.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>What advice would you give other leaders with regard to leading in crisis?</p>
<p><strong>Seth Berkley:</strong> The most important thing is to be boldbe willing to take the risks that are there. Its really important to reach out for as much help as you can get during those moments because these are really difficult challenges.</p>
<p>And when I say reach out for help, I mean in terms of asking experts to give advice, looking at other models that have worked in the past, not being egocentric, and making sure to take advantage of what science and technology have to offer to be able to move things forward. Its about being humble and understanding that when you deal with something like this, theres going to be lots of unknowns. And you need to bring people together as best as possible to tackle them.</p>

References to specific products or organizations do not constitute any endorsement or recommendation by McKinsey.</em></p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Seth Berkley</strong> is the CEO of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance. <strong><a href="/our-people/michael-conway">Michael Conway</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinseys Philadelphia office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/lieven-van-der-veken">Lieven Van der Veken</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Geneva office. </p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Astrid Sandoval, an executive editor in the London office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Finding solidarity in an effort to vaccinate the world","displayName":"Finding solidarity in an effort to vaccinate the world","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"48ec74e2-ec67-4ebf-afde-ebf1803c4a68","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Finding solidarity in an effort to vaccinate the world"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Dr. Seth Berkley, CEO of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, strengthens ties with partners to help increase global immunity in the context of COVID-19."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Gavi CEO Seth Berkley strengthens ties with partners to help increase global immunity in the context of COVID-19. "},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-07-15T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview is part of \u003c/em\u003eCOVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond\u003cem\u003e, a series that includes a broad array of voices leading the historic global effort to develop, distribute, and provide equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, including the \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery\"\u003eAfrica CDC\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/accelerating-pandemic-response-efforts-an-interview-with-cepis-richard-hatchett\"\u003eCEPI\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world\"\u003eGavi, the Vaccine Alliance\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/modernas-path-to-vaccine-innovation-a-talk-with-ceo-stephane-bancel\"\u003eModerna\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; and \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pfizers-mix-of-science-and-grit-alters-the-course-of-its-covid-19-response\"\u003ePfizer\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs long as COVID-19 is out there, \u003c/strong\u003eit\u0026rsquo;s a threat. Unless vaccine supplies are shared more equitably, it\u0026rsquo;s estimated that the world\u0026rsquo;s poorest countries will not be able to reach a vaccination rate of 60 percent until 2023 or later.[[Footnote 1]] In many ways, the impacts of that timeline could be more devastating than the immediate crisis. With disproportionate global vaccine distribution and growing concerns over the emergence of more contagious COVID-19 variants, the required protection becomes much harder to reach\u0026mdash;very possibly extending the length of the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eDr. Seth Berkley is the CEO of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, which was built to help low-income countries obtain vaccines. He knows better than most, from decades of work on vaccines, that closing immunity gaps globally is a Herculean task. But he also sees progress and a renewed cooperation and collaboration among his partners to deal with vaccine distribution more equitably. Gavi co-leads (with CEPI and WHO) COVAX, which supports the research, development, and manufacturing of a wide range of COVID-19-vaccine candidates and is the biggest global effort in history to get vaccines to developing nations.[[Footnote 2]]  \u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eGavi is in a unique position to address inequities in COVID-19-vaccine access. As the secretariat\nof an alliance comprising UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank, along with other leading global health agencies, vaccine manufacturers, and the private sector, it has spent two decades funding vaccines for lower-income countries. But one of the most important strategies for making real headway in a crisis of this magnitude is to evolve the working relationships among the alliance\u0026rsquo;s flagship organizations to heighten the core immunization measures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDr. Berkley talks with McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Michael Conway and Lieven Van der Veken about how he is reactivating private and public resources toward one of the biggest societal challenges in history. What follows is an edited excerpt of their conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eGavi\u0026rsquo;s mission is to secure vaccines for developing countries. How are you doing that with the COVID-19 vaccines?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley:\u003c/strong\u003e Historically, vaccines don\u0026rsquo;t get to the poorest nations. Over the past 20 years, Gavi\u0026rsquo;s public- and private-sector collaborations have provided close to 50 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s children with vaccines and have been able to launch more than 495 new vaccine introductions and campaigns all across the world. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 2020, given the importance of the COVID-19 outbreak, we helped launch a partnership called COVAX to accelerate the development and manufacturing of COVID-19 vaccines and guarantee fair and equitable access to them for every country in the world. So far, 193 countries and territories have come together to be part of this initiative. Through the COVAX Facility, the alliance went on to secure two billion doses of COVID-19 vaccines for the second half of 2021, with the goal of having every healthcare worker in the world immunized.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe hardest part at the beginning was not being able to move the deals as quickly as we\u0026rsquo;d like and\nnot being able to deliver as quickly as we\u0026rsquo;d like. But comparing the work of this crisis to the pandemic in 2009, we were two-and-a-half times faster and went to four times the number of countries with more than seven times the number of doses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe still have a ways to go. More than 3.47 billion vaccine doses have been administered globally,\nbut while 49.6 percent of inhabitants of high-income countries had received at least one dose of the vaccine as of July 14, only 1 percent of those in low-income countries had.[[Footnote 3]] We set up COVAX to try to get equity firmly on the agenda. We knew that had not happened in previous epidemics. We also had hoped to stop bilateral deal making as much as possible because we know that it\u0026rsquo;s not an efficient way to deal with the distribution of products equitably. We\u0026rsquo;ve done very well\u0026mdash;not necessarily getting us to equity but at least having that as part of the conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConcerning bilateral deals, there was excitement for a multilateral mechanism. People came together to work on it, but when the new variants appeared, some high- and low-income countries made additional purchases. This has led to the type of supply constraints that we knew were going to be there. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1Up dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e Can you expand on the challenges of ongoing supply constraints and what can be done to quicken equitable vaccine distribution for COVID-19 and other vaccine-preventable diseases? \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley: \u003c/strong\u003eAt first, the challenge we had was getting the financing and the vaccine approvals. We initially moved forward with two different deals: one with AstraZeneca, and the other with the Serum Institute of India.[[Footnote 4]] The latter covered distribution to the poorest 60 countries, and the former covered the rest of the world. In early 2021, we began to deliver on both of these plans. It was a little slow at the start because of the magnitude of the effort, but then it started to take off. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut we knew this wasn\u0026rsquo;t a fait accompli. There are new challenges that emerge every day during a pandemic of this scale, like the rise of new variants that test the efficacy of current vaccines, vaccine hesitancy in some countries over risk concerns, and the terrible surge of infections in India. These challenges impose additional stress on an already strained supply chain for delivering vaccines to developing countries.\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe entire world was producing about five billion doses of all types of vaccines per year prior to the pandemic. Estimates reveal a further ten billion to 14 billion doses will be needed to include COVID-19 vaccines.[[Footnote 5]] That\u0026rsquo;s a tripling of volume. Serious challenges with the supply chain will need to be dealt with. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far, we\u0026rsquo;re still seeing routine vaccines being supplied at about the same pace as they were before the COVID-19 pandemic. But considering the current global shortages, the production is likely to slow down. In some places, a lack of routine vaccine distribution could lead to additional complexities. There\u0026rsquo;s a study that suggests that due to the efforts in preventing just one COVID-19-related death, there could be 84 deaths from other vaccine-preventable diseases.[[Footnote 6]] We want to avoid that type of trade-off. An outbreak of a vaccine-preventable disease would also compound the problem by doubly overwhelming the healthcare system and healthcare workers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the longer term, we need to solve for building a more equitable manufacturing system for vaccines and make sure they are produced in different regions across different countries. We clearly\nneed more localized capacity, but it also has to be economically viable for those regions.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e Gavi has always relied on strong partnerships. What has been the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on your collaborations? Has there been an upside? \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley: \u003c/strong\u003eOne of the advantages that Gavi has is that it\u0026rsquo;s an alliance. We have working relationships with WHO, the World Bank, and UNICEF, as well as civil society and vaccine manufacturers. We\u0026rsquo;re working together every day with all of these different groups. We can bring those existing relationships together in a network-type operation versus a more siloed approach. In April 2020, this way of working resulted in the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator, which supports the development of all the tools needed to fight the disease\u0026mdash;not just the vaccines but the diagnostics, treatments, and therapeutics needed globally as well.[[Footnote 7]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis network approach is how both the surge capacity and the ability to work in different ways can be done best. For example, initially, in the year 2001, we only worked with five private-sector companies, and four of the five were in wealthy countries. Today, we have 17 suppliers, and the majority of those are in developing countries. We not only had to work with some of the same manufacturers of the past but also had to introduce new competitors in the mix, and those manufacturers were under enormous pressure to deal with high-income governments. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd so the challenge has been to help lead these companies to balance their engagements in both developed and developing countries. That was very hard at the beginning. But through more cooperation and collaboration, this way of working provides faster and stronger decision-making powers across a whole range of institutions to respond quickly and focus on specific challenges as they arise and try to solve for those.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis \u0026ldquo;network wave\u0026rdquo; is the wave of the future. If you look at the big problems in the world, they are not going to be solved by just one group, whether it\u0026rsquo;s the private sector or governments. They\u0026rsquo;re going to be solved by interesting collaborations between the private and public sectors and different groups and institutions working together. That\u0026rsquo;s how we\u0026rsquo;ll get the balance of being both agile and representative: taking into account the politics but not being consumed by it and unable to move forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e The COVID-19 pandemic has been a very difficult and dynamic period. What lessons have been learned from it? Which do you think will last?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley:\u003c/strong\u003e The world has to be prepared. It is evolutionarily certain that we will have more outbreaks. What was quickly evident to me as we began this systematic approach was the number of things that were not in place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe most trivial example was how we label the vaccines. Are they labeled for each individual country or region in different languages? Do we have a pandemic label? There were also more complicated examples. Do we have the system set up to deal with the issues of indemnification and liability and no-fault compensation? Do we have regulatory harmonization\u0026mdash;are countries willing to accept, for example, WHO prequalification or emergency use authorization as a way forward?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow that we\u0026rsquo;ve systematically put all of these measures in place, I think the challenge for us is, how do we keep them in place going forward? How do we take the existing organizations that\nare working in these spaces and build the surge capacity and financial ability but also keep the lessons learned? That way, the next time there is a pandemic, we can just jump right in and use the tools that have been put in place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e In the area of innovation, what do you see as most promising in the fight against COVID-19 and other diseases?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley:\u003c/strong\u003e First of all, on the vaccine side, it\u0026rsquo;s been unbelievable. As somebody who\u0026rsquo;s worked in vaccines for decades now, I was asked early on how long it takes to produce a new vaccine, and the fastest vaccine before this was produced in four years. The Ebola vaccine took five years. And\nhere we are, 327 days from the time the genomic sequence was done until we had a vaccine. That is extraordinary innovation. And not just one vaccine: there are 15 COVID-19 vaccines that have been approved for widespread use. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur hope is that some of these innovations can be pivoted to other diseases, whether they be regional diseases\u0026mdash;like Marburg or Congo hemorrhagic fever\u0026mdash;or whether the innovations are for diseases where we need a universal vaccine\u0026mdash;like influenza\u0026mdash;or better work\u0026mdash;like HIV or tuberculosis. I\u0026rsquo;d also like to see new tools to deliver vaccines. Can we use patch technologies? Can we use nasal or oral administrations that can make it easier to work in difficult settings, and ideally not at \u0026ndash;80\u0026deg;C? How do we achieve temperature stability?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond vaccine innovation, we need to take advantage of the digital world and the ability to track and trace. We could use barcodes to follow vaccine distribution, with identifiers that allow us\nto get real-time data that can help us manage stocks and the process better. This pandemic\nhas been an opportunity to test new systems and develop them for future use on routine\nvaccines and other health commodities.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe also have to think about how we innovate on the financing side, which has been an important part of what we\u0026rsquo;ve done. It\u0026rsquo;s brought us into areas like innovating in insurance, which is not our normal strength but was really important. For example, we were able to create a no-fault compensation scheme for the 92 poorest countries. That had never been done before.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e What are three things you want to see happen differently concerning the COVID-19 vaccines?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley: \u003c/strong\u003eThe first thing I would like to see is COVID-19-vaccine doses freed up for the poorest countries. We are just not there yet concerning this critical issue of equity. Many countries are now donating back surplus doses, and I expect more will follow. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, I want to see the volumes increase everywhere so that we can take into account domestic needs at the same time that we look at global supply. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd last\u0026mdash;and I think this is beginning to happen\u0026mdash;people need to understand that we are only safe if everyone\u0026rsquo;s safe. It\u0026rsquo;s a natural response for people to say, \u0026ldquo;I\u0026rsquo;m worried about my family, my community, my country.\u0026rdquo; But when you see a pandemic moving globally as fast as this one is, mutations occur. If there are large parts of the world that are unprotected, there\u0026rsquo;s potential risk not just for those countries but for the whole world. So how do we move to a world that, in those circumstances, doesn\u0026rsquo;t think nationally but thinks globally? That\u0026rsquo;s a critical part of the future vision of where we need to go.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eWhat advice would you give other leaders with regard to leading in crisis?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeth Berkley:\u003c/strong\u003e The most important thing is to be bold\u0026mdash;be willing to take the risks that are there. It\u0026rsquo;s really important to reach out for as much help as you can get during those moments because these are really difficult challenges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd when I say reach out for help, I mean in terms of asking experts to give advice, looking at other models that have worked in the past, not being egocentric, and making sure to take advantage of what science and technology have to offer to be able to move things forward. It\u0026rsquo;s about being humble and understanding that when you deal with something like this, there\u0026rsquo;s going to be lots of unknowns. And you need to bring people together as best as possible to tackle them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content is provided \u0026ldquo;as is\u0026rdquo; solely for informational purposes. It is not legal, health, or safety advice. Organizations should engage their own experts to ensure any adopted measures are compliant with applicable laws and standards in their jurisdictions.
